Pro Log: Opening stage of Giro d’Italia Donne cancelled, Tour de France begins in Basque Country, thumbtacks thrown onto roads, Peter Sagan receives suspended sentence

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. It’s the best time of the year, with both the women’s Giro d’Italia Donne and men’s Tour de France in full swing. After four stages in Italy, Annemiek van Vleuten (Movistar) continues to wear the leader’s maglia rosa, while Adam Yates (UAE Team Emirates) tops the general classification at the Tour de France.

The races have been corkers so far, but let’s go back to the Giro d’Italia Donne for a second…

1. Opening stage cancelled at Giro d’Italia Donne

There’s rain… and then there’s 𝐓𝐇𝐈𝐒 at the Giro d’Italia Donne pic.twitter.com/THIm5fRaHR

— Eurosport (@eurosport) June 30, 2023

Torrential rain and thunderstorms hit Tuscany on the first day of the Giro d’Italia Donne. Stage 1 was scheduled to be a 4.4km individual time-trial around Chianciano Terme. Roughly ten riders had completed the course after the stage was paused twice with Letizia Paternoster (Jayco-AlUla) in the hot seat with a time of 5:42.

Well, we trained for wet conditions but couldn’t prepare for this. Stage one of the Giro d’Italia Donne has been cancelled due to the weather. pic.twitter.com/vxKXdMoD7L

— EF Education-TIBCO-SVB (@EF_TIBCO_SVB) June 30, 2023

Paternoster didn’t get the chance to see if her time would be beaten however as the stage was then cancelled. Rider safety should always prevail and the rain on course had some sections looking like rivers, so it wasn’t a controversial decision.

2. Basque Country embraces Tour de France

Ongi etorri Euskal Herrira! Welcome to the Basque Country!

Pumped to be here and to get things rolling. pic.twitter.com/Y2Go9KnQSG

— EF Pro Cycling (@EFprocycling) June 29, 2023

Even before the 2023 Tour de France began on 1st July in Bilbao, Spain, the peloton spent time soaking up the atmosphere at the team presentation. The crowds were phenomenal with flags surrounding the riders and fans lining the roadsides.

The Basque Country first welcomed the Tour de France in 1949, with San Sebastián later hosting the 1992 Grand Départ. Understandably, it has featured more heavily in the Vuelta a España than the Tour though, notching 36 appearances over the years and most recently in last year’s Vuelta. Today’s Stage 3 of the Tour saw riders cross over the border into France.

3. Peloton hit by thumbtacks at Tour de France

Merci pour ce genre de connerie humaine … je pense ne pas avoir été le seul victime de crevaison dans le final … sachez qu’on peut tomber et se faire très mal avec vos conneries bande d’abrutis … pic.twitter.com/IoTMolFKgO

— Lilian Calmejane (@L_Calmejane) July 2, 2023

Stage 2 of the Tour de France was a 209km day from Vitoria-Gasteiz to Saint-Sebastián. Victor Lafay (Cofidis) broke away under the flamme rouge and stayed ahead of the sprinters to finally break the team’s 15-year stage win drought at the race. 15 years! They finally got to pop the bottle that has been waiting in the team bus.

After the finish, it was revealed that riders had encountered thumbtacks on the road near the Jaizkibel climb with 40km to go, Jumbo-Visma coach Grischa Niermann confirmed to Eurosport. Around 20 riders had been affected including Lilian Calmejane (AG2R-Citroen) and Tom Pidcock (Ineos Grenadiers).

‘Know that we can fall and get really hurt with this stupidity, you morons,’ Calmejane wrote on Twitter.

4. Peter Sagan given suspended sentence for drink driving

Peter Sagan (TotalEnergies) was given a suspended prison sentence for drink driving after police noticed ‘dangerous behaviour’ while he was riding a scooter in May. In the report published by Monaco Matin, police stopped Sagan in Monaco as he attempted to park his scooter and saw his drunken state. Two tests confirmed excessively high alcohol levels and the 33-year-old received a three-month suspended prison sentence. He also cannot drive during this period.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Peter Sagan (@petosagan)

Sagan’s lawyers attempted to argue that he had been ‘feeling the effects of jetlag’ and was unaware of his alcohol levels. He apologised on Instagram.
